title: Playwright E2E test infrastructure — setup, config, screenshot baseline
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-hk4c
attached_at: 2026-02-14T04:02:13Z
attached_args: P0 URGENT. Set up Playwright with visual regression (toHaveScreenshot). This unblocks 3 test suite beads. Move fast.
dispatched_by: mayor

Set up Playwright E2E testing infrastructure:

1. Install @playwright/test in apps/web
2. playwright.config.ts: baseURL localhost:3000, browsers (chromium, firefox, webkit), screenshot on failure
3. Visual regression setup:
   - toHaveScreenshot() for every key page
   - Screenshot baseline directory: apps/web/tests/screenshots/
   - Threshold config for pixel diff tolerance
   - CI-friendly: update snapshots flag
4. Test utilities:
   - Auth helper: mock Supabase auth for test user (consumer, farmer, rider roles)
   - Database seeding: test fixtures for produce, trips, orders, ratings
   - Page object models for key pages
5. Global setup: seed test DB, create test users
6. Global teardown: cleanup
7. npm scripts: test:e2e, test:e2e:update-snapshots, test:e2e:headed
8. GitHub Actions workflow for E2E on PR

Reference: Playwright docs for visual comparisons — toHaveScreenshot(), toMatchSnapshot()

title: Real-time order pings — notify in-transit riders of nearby orders
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-la1f
attached_at: 2026-02-14T03:11:56Z
dispatched_by: mayor

Ping riders with new orders along their active route:

1. When new order placed, find in_transit riders whose route passes near pickup AND delivery
2. Use ST_DWithin on rider's remaining route segment (not full route)
3. Send real-time ping via Supabase channel (rider:{rider_id}:pings)
4. Ping shows: pickup location, delivery location, weight, earnings, detour distance
5. Rider accepts/declines within timeout (5 min)
6. First-accept wins, update order status to matched
7. Recalculate rider route with new stops via OSRM
8. Push notification as backup if rider app is backgrounded

Reference: spec.md Section 8.2, Section 10

title: eSewa payment integration — escrow, consumer payment, farmer/rider payouts
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-v28m
attached_at: 2026-02-14T02:45:17Z

Integrate eSewa (Nepal's top digital wallet) for payments:

1. eSewa SDK integration (web + mobile)
2. Consumer pays via eSewa at checkout (alternative to cash)
3. Platform holds payment in escrow until delivery confirmed
4. On delivery confirmation: release produce cost to farmer, delivery fee to rider
5. Escrow release via eSewa merchant API
6. Payment status tracking in orders table (payment_method=esewa, payment_status progression)
7. Refund flow for cancelled/disputed orders
8. Transaction history for all parties

Reference: spec.md Section 3.4, Section 10
notes: Implemented eSewa payment integration: escrow flow, payment method selection (cash/eSewa), HMAC signature verification, server-to-server verification, escrow release on delivery, refund on cancellation, retry payment flow, bilingual i18n. New migration: esewa_transactions table. 5 new files, 8 modified files.

Every test must call expect(page).toHaveScreenshot() at key interaction points.

title: Admin dashboard — user management, order management, dispute resolution
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-u9pq
attached_at: 2026-02-14T02:45:37Z

Build admin dashboard for platform operators:

1. Admin auth (separate admin role or superuser flag)
2. User management: list users, view profiles, ban/suspend, verify farmers
3. Order management: list all orders, filter by status, view details, force-resolve
4. Dispute resolution: list disputes, view evidence (photos), mediate, refund
5. Platform stats: total orders, revenue (delivery fees), active users, top farmers
6. Farmer verification queue: review submitted documents, approve/reject
7. Content moderation: flag inappropriate listings

Web only (Next.js admin routes under /[locale]/admin/).
Reference: spec.md Section 10
notes: Implemented admin dashboard with: (1) is_admin flag on users table with admin RLS policies including WITH CHECK, (2) admin auth guard (requireAdmin), (3) platform stats dashboard, (4) user management with search/filter/detail views, (5) order management with status filter and force-resolve/cancel/dispute actions, (6) dispute resolution view filtering disputed orders, (7) farmer verification queue with approve/reject. Full i18n (en+ne). TypeScript clean.

Reference: spec.md Sections 4.1, 4.2, 4.3

title: Farmer produce listing — CRUD with photos, pricing, categories
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-sh6
attached_at: 2026-02-13T18:35:51Z

Build the farmer-facing produce listing system:

Web (Next.js):
1. Farmer dashboard at /[lang]/farmer/dashboard — shows active listings, pending orders, earnings
2. Add listing page at /[lang]/farmer/listings/new — form with: category (dropdown from produce_categories), name, description, price per kg, available quantity, freshness date, photos (up to 5), location (auto from profile or pin on map)
3. Edit listing at /[lang]/farmer/listings/[id]/edit
4. Toggle listing active/inactive
5. Photo upload to Supabase Storage (compress client-side before upload, max 1MB each)

API:
- POST /produce — create listing
- PATCH /produce/:id — update
- DELETE /produce/:id — soft delete (is_active=false)
- GET /produce?farmer_id=X — farmer's own listings

Seed produce_categories with ~30 common Nepal items:
Vegetables: tomato, potato, onion, cauliflower, cabbage, spinach, radish, carrot, beans, peas, chili, garlic, ginger, mushroom, cucumber
Fruits: apple, orange, banana, mango, guava, papaya, lemon, pomegranate
Grains: rice, wheat, maize, millet
Dairy: milk, curd, ghee

Reference: spec.md Section 4.1, 5.1

comments.author: jirisewa/polecats/guzzle
comments.text: Implemented farmer produce listing CRUD system. 3 commits: Supabase client setup + DB types + category seeds + photo storage bucket, then full CRUD implementation (dashboard, listing form, photo upload, server actions, bilingual i18n), then review fixes (security lockdown, error handling, data accuracy). Type-check, lint, and build all pass.

title: OSM map integration — Leaflet for web, flutter_map for mobile
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-727
attached_at: 2026-02-13T18:22:20Z

Integrate OpenStreetMap across the platform:

Web (Leaflet + react-leaflet):
1. Location picker component: click-to-pin on map, reverse geocode for address
2. Produce listing map: show nearby listings as markers
3. Trip route display: draw route polyline on map
4. Order tracking map placeholder (real-time tracking is Phase 2)

Mobile (flutter_map):
1. Same components: location picker, route display, listing markers
2. GPS location access for rider tracking
3. Offline tile caching for areas with poor connectivity (using flutter_map tile layer)

Shared:
- Tile server: https://tile.openstreetmap.org/{z}/{x}/{y}.png (free, attribution required)
- Geocoding: Nominatim (public instance, respect rate limits)
- Routing: OSRM public demo server for MVP
- Default map center: Jiri (27.6306, 86.2305) for the launch area
- Nepal bounding box for map constraints: [26.347, 80.058] to [30.447, 88.201]

Reference: spec.md Section 3.3
notes: Implemented OSM map integration across web and mobile. Web: 4 react-leaflet components (LocationPicker, ProduceMap, TripRouteMap, OrderTrackingMap) with dynamic SSR-safe imports. Mobile: 3 flutter_map widgets (LocationPickerWidget, RouteMapWidget, ListingsMapWidget) with GPS support. Shared: map constants in @jirisewa/shared, Nominatim geocoding service, OSRM routing service. All type-checks, lint, Flutter analysis, and build pass clean.

title: Consumer marketplace — browse produce, search, filter, product detail
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-nic
attached_at: 2026-02-13T18:35:29Z

Build the consumer-facing marketplace:

Web (Next.js, SSR for SEO):
1. Marketplace page at /[lang]/marketplace — grid of produce listings
   - Filter by: category, price range, location/distance
   - Search by name (bilingual)
   - Sort by: price, distance, freshness, rating
   - Pagination (infinite scroll or page-based)
   - Each card: photo, name, price/kg, farmer name+rating, distance, freshness
2. Product detail at /[lang]/produce/[id] — full listing with all photos, farmer profile link, add to cart
3. Category pages at /[lang]/marketplace/[category] — SEO-friendly category browsing
4. Location picker: consumer sets their location (geolocation API or manual pin) to calculate distances

SSR: Product detail pages must be server-rendered with proper meta tags (og:image, description) for sharing on Facebook/Viber.

API:
- GET /produce — with filters (category_id, min_price, max_price, lat, lng, radius_km, search, sort_by)
- GET /produce/:id — single listing with farmer info

Reference: spec.md Section 4.2, 6.2
notes:
Implemented consumer marketplace:
- Marketplace page (/[locale]/marketplace) with produce grid, filters, search, sort, load-more
- Product detail page (/[locale]/produce/[id]) with SSR, OG meta tags for social sharing
- Category browsing (/[locale]/marketplace/[category])
- Location picker (Geolocation API) for distance-based produce search
- Supabase client setup (server + browser) with typed schema
- PostGIS RPC function (search_produce_listings) for geospatial queries
- API routes: GET /api/produce (with filters), GET /api/produce/:id, GET /api/categories
- Produce category seed data (12 categories, bilingual)
- Full bilingual i18n (en/ne) for all marketplace strings
- Flat design system compliance
- Input validation, AbortController for race conditions, LIKE metacharacter escaping

title: Landing page — hero, how it works, stats, CTA sections
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-i25
attached_at: 2026-02-13T18:35:09Z

Build the JiriSewa landing page following ui.md flat design system:

Route: /[lang]/ (bilingual, default Nepali)

Sections (each is a bold color block per ui.md):
1. HERO (Blue bg #3B82F6):
   - Large heading: 'किसानबाट सिधै तपाईंको घरमा' / 'Fresh from farm to your door'
   - Subheading explaining the three-sided marketplace concept
   - Two CTAs: 'Browse Produce' (white button), 'Become a Rider' (outline border-4 white)
   - Background decoration: large geometric shapes (circles, rotated squares) at low opacity
   - Abstract illustration of farmer→rider→consumer flow using geometric shapes

2. HOW IT WORKS (Dark gray #111827 bg, white text):
   - 3 steps with large numbered circles
   - Step 1 (Emerald icon): Farmer lists produce
   - Step 2 (Amber icon): Rider posts trip
   - Step 3 (Blue icon): Consumer orders, rider delivers
   - Each step is a flat card with icon circle (h-16 w-16)

3. STATS (White bg):
   - Multi-color stat numbers per ui.md bold factor
   - Stats: Farmers registered, KG delivered, Riders active, Avg savings %
   - Use placeholder numbers for MVP

4. FOR FARMERS (Emerald bg #10B981):
   - Benefits of listing on JiriSewa
   - CTA: 'Start Selling' button

5. FOR RIDERS (Amber bg #F59E0B):
   - Benefits of riding with JiriSewa
   - CTA: 'Start Earning' button

6. CTA SECTION (Blue bg):
   - Final call to action
   - Download / sign up prompt

7. FOOTER (Dark gray bg):
   - Links, contact (info@jirisewa.com), social placeholders
   - OSM attribution

All sections: NO shadows, bold typography (Outfit 700/800), geometric purity, poster aesthetic.
Responsive: mobile-first, stack on small screens, grid on large.

Reference: ui.md, spec.md Section 2
notes: Implemented full landing page with all 7 sections: Hero (blue, bilingual heading, dual CTAs, farmer→rider→consumer illustration), How It Works (dark bg, 3 numbered steps with IconCircle), Stats (white bg, multi-color numbers), For Farmers (emerald bg, benefits list), For Riders (amber bg, benefits list), CTA (blue bg, sign-up prompt), Footer (dark bg, links/contact/social/OSM attribution). Added 'dark' SectionBlock variant. Fully bilingual via next-intl message files. Mobile-first responsive. Build and lint pass.

dispatched_by: mayor

Build the rider trip management system:

Mobile (Flutter) + Web fallback:
1. Post trip screen: origin (pin or search), destination (pin or search), departure date/time, available capacity (kg), vehicle type
2. Route display: show calculated route on OSM map using OSRM
3. My trips list: upcoming, active, completed
4. Trip detail: route on map, matched orders, pickup/drop sequence
5. Edit trip (only before departure)
6. Cancel trip (notify matched orders)
7. Start trip button → changes status to in_transit

Web (Next.js):
- Rider dashboard at /[lang]/rider/dashboard
- Post trip at /[lang]/rider/trips/new
- Trip detail at /[lang]/rider/trips/[id]

API:
- POST /trips — create trip with origin, destination, departure_at, available_capacity_kg
- GET /trips — list rider's trips (filter by status)
- GET /trips/:id — trip detail with matched orders
- PATCH /trips/:id — update trip
- POST /trips/:id/start — mark in_transit
- POST /trips/:id/complete — mark completed
- DELETE /trips/:id — cancel (only if scheduled)

Route calculation:
- Call OSRM API: GET /route/v1/driving/{origin_lng},{origin_lat};{dest_lng},{dest_lat}?overview=full&geometries=geojson
- Store route as LineString in rider_trips.route
- Use public OSRM demo server for MVP (router.project-osrm.org)

Reference: spec.md Section 4.3, 6.3

title: E2E tests: consumer flows — marketplace, produce detail, cart, checkout, order tracking
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-nqwc
attached_at: 2026-02-14T04:20:21Z

Playwright E2E tests for consumer experience:

TESTS (each with screenshot validation):
1. Landing page loads correctly
   - Screenshot: hero section, how-it-works, stats, CTA
   - Verify bilingual toggle (en/ne)

2. Marketplace browsing
   - Screenshot: marketplace grid with produce cards
   - Filter by category → screenshot filtered results
   - Search for produce → screenshot search results
   - Screenshot: empty state when no results

3. Produce detail page
   - Navigate from marketplace → produce detail
   - Screenshot: produce detail with photos, price, farmer info
   - Add to cart button works

4. Cart and checkout
   - Add multiple items to cart
   - Screenshot: cart page with items, quantities, totals
   - Adjust quantities, remove items
   - Proceed to checkout
   - Screenshot: checkout with delivery address, payment method
   - Place order → screenshot: order confirmation

5. Order tracking
   - Navigate to orders list
   - Screenshot: orders list with status badges
   - Click order → screenshot: order detail with timeline
   - Verify status progression display

6. Rating flow
   - After delivered order, show rating modal
   - Screenshot: rating modal with stars
   - Submit rating → screenshot: updated order with rating

Every test must call expect(page).toHaveScreenshot() at key interaction points.
Depends on: Playwright infrastructure bead

title: Real-time rider tracking — live location on consumer order map
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-gxwj
attached_at: 2026-02-14T02:46:19Z

Implement live rider tracking during delivery:

1. Rider app: GPS location broadcast via Supabase Realtime channel (trip:{trip_id})
2. Location updates every 10 seconds while trip is in_transit
3. Consumer order page: live map showing rider position along route
4. ETA calculation using OSRM based on remaining route distance + rider speed
5. Status transitions shown on map (picked up markers, delivery marker)
6. Auto-stop tracking when trip completes or is cancelled
7. Battery optimization on mobile (reduce frequency when app backgrounded)
8. Leverage existing rider_location_log table and map components from Phase 1

Reference: spec.md Section 5.1, Section 6.6, Section 10

title: Push notifications — Firebase Cloud Messaging for web and mobile
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-w1x9
attached_at: 2026-02-14T02:45:58Z

Replace SMS-only notifications with push:

1. Firebase Cloud Messaging setup (web + Flutter)
2. Device token registration and storage (new table: user_devices)
3. Notification triggers:
   - Consumer: order matched, rider picked up, rider arriving, delivered
   - Farmer: new order for their produce, rider arriving for pickup
   - Rider: new order match, trip reminder, delivery confirmed
4. Notification preferences (user can toggle categories)
5. In-app notification center (bell icon with unread count)
6. Fallback to SMS for users without push tokens

Reference: spec.md Section 10
notes:
Implemented push notifications with FCM for web and mobile:
- Database: user_devices, notifications, notification_preferences tables with RLS
- Edge function: send-notification with FCM push + SMS fallback (Sparrow SMS)
- Web: Firebase client setup, NotificationBell with unread count, NotificationPreferences page, PushNotificationManager for auto-registration
- Mobile: PushNotificationService with FCM init, token registration, foreground/background handling
- Integration: Order lifecycle triggers (placeOrder→farmer, confirmPickup→consumer, confirmDelivery→rider)
- i18n: Full English and Nepali translations
- Security: create_notification restricted to service_role, edge function auth validated, HTTPS for SMS API

title: Rating system — post-delivery ratings for farmers and riders
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-c08x
attached_at: 2026-02-14T02:38:08Z
dispatched_by: mayor

Implement the rating/review system:

1. After order delivery is confirmed, prompt consumer to rate:
   - Farmer: produce quality (1-5 stars + comment)
   - Rider: delivery quality (1-5 stars + comment)
2. Farmer can rate rider (cooperation, timeliness)
3. Rider can rate farmer (produce readiness, accuracy)
4. Rating display: show avg rating + count on user profiles, listing cards, trip listings
5. Update users.rating_avg and users.rating_count via trigger or app logic
6. Ratings are public and immutable (no editing/deleting)

Web:
- Rating form as modal after delivery confirmation
- Rating display on farmer profile, produce cards, rider profile

API:
- POST /orders/:id/rate — submit rating (validates: order is delivered, rater is party to order, hasn't already rated)
- GET /users/:id/ratings — paginated list of ratings received

Reference: spec.md Section 5.1 (ratings table), Section 6.5

title: Design system setup — Tailwind tokens, Outfit font, base components
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-rx9
attached_at: 2026-02-13T18:22:01Z

Implement the design system from ui.md as reusable Tailwind config and base components:

Tailwind config (tailwind.config.ts):
- Colors: primary=#3B82F6, secondary=#10B981, accent=#F59E0B, muted=#F3F4F6, foreground=#111827
- Font: Outfit (Google Fonts import)
- No shadow utilities used (shadow-none enforced)
- Radius defaults: rounded-md (6px), rounded-lg (8px)

Base components (apps/web/src/components/ui/):
- Button: primary (solid blue, white text, h-14, hover:scale-105), secondary (gray-100 bg), outline (border-4, fill on hover)
- Card: solid bg, no shadow, no border, p-6/p-8, rounded-lg, hover:scale-[1.02]
- Input: bg-gray-100 normal, white bg + border-2 primary on focus
- SectionBlock: alternating bg colors (white/muted/primary/secondary/accent), geometric decoration
- IconCircle: lucide icon inside colored circle (h-14 w-14)
- Badge: pill-shaped tag with accent colors

All components must follow ui.md strictly:
- ZERO box shadows anywhere
- Scale transforms for hover feedback
- Outfit font, geometric aesthetic
- Bold color blocking for sections
- lucide-react for all icons

Reference: ui.md (entire document)

title: Bilingual i18n — Nepali and English with [lang] routing
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-fwk
attached_at: 2026-02-13T18:22:40Z

Implement bilingual support across the web app:

1. Route structure: /[lang]/... where lang is 'en' or 'ne'
2. Default language: ne (Nepali)
3. Language switcher in header (toggle between en/ne)
4. Translation files: JSON-based, one per language
5. Server-side language detection: Accept-Language header → cookie → default ne
6. All UI text, form labels, error messages, category names in both languages
7. Produce listings have name_en and name_ne fields — show based on current lang
8. SEO: hreflang tags, canonical URLs per language
9. Date/number formatting: Nepali uses same numerals as English in practice (no Devanagari digits needed for MVP)

Use next-intl or a lightweight i18n approach. Keep it simple — no ICU message format needed for MVP.

Reference: spec.md Section 12

title: Multi-farmer orders — single order with items from multiple farms
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-j6vb
attached_at: 2026-02-14T03:09:52Z

Allow consumers to order from multiple farmers in one checkout:

1. Cart already supports items from different farmers (order_items has farmer_id)
2. Order matching: find rider trips that pass near ALL pickup locations
3. If no single trip covers all pickups, split into sub-orders per farmer
4. Rider sees multi-stop pickup sequence optimized by route order
5. Per-farmer pickup confirmation (each farmer confirms their items)
6. Partial delivery handling (what if one farmer's items unavailable)
7. Payment splitting: each farmer gets their portion

Reference: spec.md Section 10
notes: Implemented: Multi-farmer order support — DB migration (order_item_status, payout_status enums, farmer_payouts table, PostGIS RPCs), trip matching algorithm using ST_DWithin/ST_LineLocatePoint, per-farmer pickup confirmation with auto-order transition, partial delivery handling (mark-unavailable with payout refund), farmer payout tracking (create→settle→refund lifecycle), checkout/order-detail/rider-trip-detail UI updates with farmer grouping and per-farmer action buttons, eSewa delivery fee integration, EN/NE i18n strings.

title: Phone OTP authentication — Supabase Auth with Nepal SMS provider
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-iua
attached_at: 2026-02-13T18:36:11Z

Implement phone-number-based OTP authentication:

1. Supabase Auth config for phone auth
2. SMS provider integration (Sparrow SMS or Aakash SMS — pick whichever has a simpler API)
3. Auth flow: enter phone → receive OTP → verify → JWT session
4. Registration completion: after first OTP verify, collect name, location (pin on map), preferred language
5. Role selection: farmer, consumer, rider (can select multiple)
6. Role-specific fields: farm_name (farmer), vehicle_type + capacity (rider)
7. Web: Next.js auth pages at /[lang]/auth/login and /[lang]/auth/register
8. Mobile: Flutter auth screens

Nepali phone numbers: 98XXXXXXXX (10 digits). Validate format before sending OTP.

Reference: spec.md Section 4, Section 6.1

comments.author: jirisewa/polecats/shiny
comments.text: Implemented phone OTP auth: Supabase Auth + @supabase/ssr for web (Next.js), supabase_flutter for mobile. Login flow with Nepal phone validation, OTP verification with brute-force protection, and multi-step registration (name, language, address, role selection with role-specific fields). Bilingual UI (en/ne). All lint/type-check/build/tests pass.

title: Delivery fee calculator — distance and weight based pricing
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-4f97
attached_at: 2026-02-14T02:47:04Z

Replace rider-set flat fees with calculated delivery pricing:

1. Base fee + per-km rate + per-kg rate
2. Distance calculation via OSRM (actual road distance, not straight line)
3. Weight from order items total
4. Surge pricing for high-demand routes/times (optional)
5. Fee preview at checkout before order placement
6. Fee breakdown shown to consumer (base + distance + weight)
7. Admin-configurable rate table

Reference: spec.md Section 10

title: Flutter rider app — trip management, order acceptance, pickup/delivery flow
description:
Build the core rider experience in Flutter:

1. Rider dashboard: active trips, earnings summary, pending order matches
2. Post trip screen: origin/destination (LocationPicker), date/time, capacity
3. Trip detail screen: route map (RouteMap widget), matched orders, pickup sequence
4. Active trip flow: start trip → navigate pickups → confirm pickups (photo) → deliver → confirm delivery
5. Order acceptance: view matched order details, accept/decline
6. Earnings history screen
7. Wire to Supabase: rider_trips CRUD, orders query by rider_id, order status updates
8. Use existing map widgets (LocationPicker, RouteMap, ListingsMap)
9. Use existing auth flow and Supabase client

Existing infrastructure: auth screens, map widgets, geocoding service, theme system, Supabase connected.
Missing: ALL rider feature screens.

Reference: spec.md Section 4.3

title: Order system — cart, checkout, order lifecycle, pickup/delivery confirmation
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-unt8
attached_at: 2026-02-14T02:06:31Z
dispatched_by: mayor

Build the full order lifecycle:

Consumer flow (Web + Mobile):
1. Cart: add items from marketplace, adjust quantities, see subtotals
2. Checkout: review cart, set delivery address (pin on map), select delivery window from available rider trips, see delivery fee estimate
3. Place order → creates order + order_items records, status=pending
4. Order tracking page: shows current status, rider info (once matched), map (Phase 2)
5. Confirm delivery: consumer taps confirm when produce received
6. Rate: prompt to rate farmer and rider (1-5 stars + optional comment)

Rider flow (Mobile):
1. See matched orders on trip dashboard
2. Accept/decline individual orders
3. Pickup: navigate to farmer, photograph produce, confirm pickup (both farmer and rider confirm in-app)
4. Delivery: navigate to consumer, hand over produce, confirm delivery
5. Collect cash from consumer (MVP payment)

Order matching (background):
- When order is placed, find scheduled trips where:
  - ST_DWithin(farmer.location, trip.route, 5000) — within 5km of route
  - ST_DWithin(consumer.delivery_location, trip.route, 5000)
  - trip.remaining_capacity_kg >= order total weight
  - trip.departure_at within consumer's delivery window
- Rank by: least detour, highest rider rating, soonest departure
- Notify top rider, first-accept wins
- If no match in 24h, notify consumer

Status flow: pending → matched → picked_up → in_transit → delivered → (rated)
Cancel flow: pending/matched → cancelled (notify all parties)

API: See spec.md Section 6.4

Reference: spec.md Section 4.2, 4.3, 5.1, 6.4, 8

title: Database schema — core tables with PostGIS, RLS policies, indexes
description:
attached_molecule: ts-wisp-u4f
attached_at: 2026-02-13T18:21:41Z

Create Supabase migrations for the core data model:

Tables:
- users (id, phone, name, role, avatar_url, location Point, address, municipality, lang, rating_avg, rating_count)
- user_roles (id, user_id, role, farm_name, vehicle_type, vehicle_capacity_kg, license_photo_url, verified)
- produce_categories (id, name_en, name_ne, icon, sort_order)
- produce_listings (id, farmer_id, category_id, name_en, name_ne, description, price_per_kg, available_qty_kg, freshness_date, location Point, photos text[], is_active)
- rider_trips (id, rider_id, origin Point, origin_name, destination Point, destination_name, route LineString, departure_at, available_capacity_kg, remaining_capacity_kg, status enum)
- orders (id, consumer_id, rider_trip_id, rider_id, status enum, delivery_address, delivery_location Point, total_price, delivery_fee, payment_method, payment_status)
- order_items (id, order_id, listing_id, farmer_id, quantity_kg, price_per_kg, subtotal, pickup_location Point, pickup_confirmed, pickup_photo_url, delivery_confirmed)
- ratings (id, order_id, rater_id, rated_id, role_rated, score 1-5, comment)
- rider_location_log (id, rider_id, trip_id, location Point, speed_kmh, recorded_at) — partitioned, 7-day TTL

PostGIS indexes on all geography columns. RLS policies: users see own data, public read on listings/categories.

Reference: spec.md Section 5
notes: Implemented: 3 Supabase migration files creating all 9 core tables (users, user_roles, produce_categories, produce_listings, rider_trips, orders, order_items, ratings, rider_location_log), PostGIS GIST indexes on all 8 geography columns, composite indexes for common query patterns, RLS policies (public read on listings/categories, own-data access elsewhere), partitioned rider_location_log with daily partitions and 7-day TTL maintenance functions.

title: Run full E2E suite, generate screenshot baselines, commit to repo
description:
After all 3 E2E test beads are merged, run the full test suite and commit screenshots:

1. Pull latest master with all Playwright tests
2. Install dependencies: pnpm install && npx playwright install --with-deps
3. Start the dev server: pnpm dev (or build + start for production-like tests)
4. Run Playwright with screenshot update mode:
   npx playwright test --update-snapshots
5. This generates all baseline screenshots in apps/web/tests/*.spec.ts-snapshots/
6. Review generated screenshots — ensure they look correct (no broken layouts, correct colors, bilingual content)
7. Organize screenshots:
   - apps/web/tests/screenshots/ for browsable reference
   - Copy key screenshots to docs/screenshots/ for the README
8. Commit ALL screenshot baselines to the repo:
   - git add apps/web/tests/**/*-snapshots/
   - git add docs/screenshots/
   - Commit message: 'test: add E2E screenshot baselines for visual regression'
9. Push to master
10. Run tests again WITHOUT --update-snapshots to verify they pass against baselines
11. If any tests fail, fix the tests or regenerate baselines

The screenshots must be IN the repo so future PRs can diff against them.

IMPORTANT: The dev server needs Supabase running. If no local Supabase, mock the API or use test fixtures from the Playwright global setup.
